categories.name: Syntax & Compilation
categories.description: Code compiles without errors, proper syntax and language conventions, appropriate use of language features relevant to Variables and Data Types, Functions/Methods, Input/Output Operations, Code Organization, Comments and Documentation, Problem Solving Approaches.

categories.name: Logic & Correctness

categories.name: Output & Functionality

categories.name: Style & Documentation
categories.description: Clear variable and function names, proper indentation and formatting, appropriate comments, follows coding best practices.

category_scores.reasoning: The code compiles and runs without errors. It uses standard Java syntax and conventions. However, the `displayInfo` method's output format isn't perfectly aligned with the sample output which showed values on separate lines more explicitly.

All requirements for the `Cuboid` class were implemented correctly. Both constructors are present and function as specified, including the chained constructor. All required methods (`getSurfaceArea`, `getVolume`, getters, `displayInfo`) are implemented correctly and produce accurate calculations. The test program creates and uses the `Cuboid` objects as required.

The program fulfills all functional requirements. The methods calculate and return correct values. The `displayInfo` method shows the cuboid's information. The minor deduction is due to the output format not exactly matching the sample output, where dimensions, surface area, and volume were more distinctly separated. The sample output implies specific line breaks and labels that are slightly different.

The code follows good style conventions. Variable and method names are clear and descriptive. Indentation and formatting are consistent. There are no comments or documentation, which is a minor omission for a complete score, but the code is otherwise well-structured and readable.

feedback.overall_comment: Excellent work! The `Cuboid` class and its test program are well-implemented and meet all the core requirements of the assignment. The code is logically correct, and the calculations for surface area and volume are accurate. The use of constructors, getters, and instance methods is appropriate. With a few minor adjustments to the output formatting and adding some comments, this submission would be perfect.
strengths: Correct implementation of `Cuboid` class with all required attributes and methods.
Accurate calculations for surface area and volume.
Proper use of constructors, including the chained constructor.
Effective test program creating and displaying information for multiple `Cuboid` objects.
Good adherence to Java naming conventions and code formatting.
areas_for_improvement: Refine the `displayInfo` method to more closely match the exact output format shown in the sample, ensuring clear labeling and spacing for each piece of information.
Add Javadoc comments to the class and methods to explain their purpose, parameters, and return values, which is a standard practice for documentation.

category_scores.reasoning: Code compiles cleanly, follows Java naming conventions, proper use of this() delegation, correct access modifiers, no syntax errors.
All algorithms correctly implemented: surface-area formula 2(lw+lh+wh) and volume formula lwh; constructors initialize fields as specified; both default and parameterized paths tested.
Both objects created and displayed, correct values calculated, but output format deviates slightly from expectedâ€”concatenates all dimension labels on one line instead of separating them.
Consistent indentation and spacing, clear variable names, methods properly separated, no magic numbers, meets Java style conventions.

feedback.overall_comment: Excellent implementation that satisfies all functional requirements. The program compiles, runs, and produces correct calculations. The only minor issue is the displayInfo() formatting; the rest of the code demonstrates strong understanding of Java classes, constructors, and encapsulation.
areas_for_improvement: Adjust displayInfo() to match exact sample formatting (e.g., separate lines for each piece of data)
